title: Towards Stable WiFi-based HAR from Imbalanced Data and Changing Circumstances

rating.justification: High-impact research addressing fundamental challenges in WiFi HAR through novel optimization framework, published in top-tier journal, demonstrates significant performance improvements with theoretical rigor

technical_innovations.algorithmic: Class Region Flattening (CRF) framework with class-conditional flat minima search
technical_innovations.mathematical: Perturbative PAC-Bayesian Generalization Theory extension for wireless sensing
technical_innovations.system: Selective flattening strategy (CRF-S) with similarity-based gradient selection
technical_innovations.optimization: Unified approach to imbalanced learning and domain adaptation through geometric optimization

mathematical_framework.convergence: First-order Taylor approximation with error bound |R_2| ≤ 5 × 10^-15

practical_implementation.hardware: Intel 5300 NIC with commodity WiFi hardware
practical_implementation.processing: Hampel filtering, PCA dimensionality reduction, STFT analysis
practical_implementation.deployment: Adaptive hyperparameter selection for diverse environments

research_significance.theoretical_contribution: First unified framework for imbalanced learning and domain adaptation in WiFi HAR
research_significance.practical_impact: Addresses critical barriers to commercial WiFi sensing deployment
research_significance.methodological_innovation: Class-conditional optimization paradigm for wireless sensing
research_significance.industry_relevance: Direct applicability to smart home, healthcare, industrial monitoring

limitations.computational_cost: Dual gradient computations increase training overhead
limitations.hyperparameter_sensitivity: Requires careful tuning of multiple parameters
limitations.activity_complexity: Evaluation limited to basic indoor activities

future_directions: Higher-order perturbation methods for advanced optimization
Online adaptation mechanisms for dynamic environments
Federated learning integration for distributed deployments
